translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Discourse on Kokālika
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Blessed One was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho kokālikaḥ bhikkhu yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho kokālikaḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the monk Kokālika went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side and said to the Blessed One:

original: “pāpicchā, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānā, pāpikānaṁ icchānaṁ vasaṁ gatā”ti.
analyzed: pāpa icchā bhante sāriputta moggallānā pāpikānam icchānam vasam gatā ati
translated: “Venerable sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna are of evil wishes, slaves to their evil wishes.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā kokālikaṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhagavā kokālikam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the Blessed One said to the monk Kokālika:

analyzed: mā ha iva kokālika mā ha iva kokālika
translated: “Do not say that, Kokālika! Do not say that, Kokālika!
Have confidence, Kokālika, in Sāriputta and Moggallāna.
They are good monks.”
A second time…

original: tatiyampi kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho kokālikaḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: A third time the monk Kokālika said to the Blessed One:

original: “kiñcāpi me, bhante, bhagavā saddhāyiko paccayiko, atha kho pāpicchāva sāriputtamoggallānā, pāpikānaṁ icchānaṁ vasaṁ gatā”ti.
analyzed: kiñca api me bhante bhagavā saddhāyikaḥ paccayikaḥ atha kho pāpicchāva sāriputta moggallānā pāpikānam icchānam vasam gatā ati
translated: “Even though the Buddha is my guarantor and reference, Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna are still evil, and they’re under the sway of bad desires.”

original: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā kokālikaṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: tatiyam pi kho bhagavā kokālikam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: For a third time, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

analyzed: mā ha iva kokālika mā ha iva kokālika
translated: “Don’t say that, Kokālika, don’t say that.
Have confidence in Sāriputta and Mahāmoggallāna.
They’re good monks.”

original: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: atha kho kokālikaḥ bhikkhu uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi
translated: Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

original: Acirappakkantassa ca kokālikassa bhikkhuno sāsapamattīhi piḷakāhi sabbo kāyo phuṭo ahosi;
analyzed: acira ppakkantassa ca kokālikassa bhikkhuno sāsapa mattīhi piḷakāhi sabbaḥ kāyaḥ phuṭaḥ ahosi
translated: Soon after his departure, his whole body became covered with boils the size of mustard seeds.🔽These boils grew to the size of mung beans,

original: sāsapamattiyo hutvā muggamattiyo ahesuṁ; muggamattiyo hutvā kaḷāyamattiyo ahesuṁ;🔽kaḷāyamattiyo hutvā kolaṭṭhimattiyo ahesuṁ; kolaṭṭhimattiyo hutvā kolamattiyo ahesuṁ;
analyzed: sāsapa mattiyaḥ hutvā mugga mattiyaḥ ahesu mugga mattiyaḥ hutvā kaḷāya mattiyaḥ ahesu 🔽kaḷāya mattiyaḥ hutvā kolaṭṭhi mattiyaḥ ahesu kolaṭṭhi mattiyaḥ hutvā kola mattiyaḥ ahesu
translated: black beans, chickpeas, and then jujube seeds.

original: kolamattiyo hutvā āmalakamattiyo ahesuṁ; āmalakamattiyo hutvā beḷuvasalāṭukamattiyo
analyzed: kola mattiyaḥ hutvā āmalaka mattiyaḥ ahesu āmalaka mattiyaḥ hutvā beḷuvasalāṭuka mattiyaḥ
translated: the size of a kola fruit, the size of an āmalaka fruit, the size of a betel nut,

original: ahesuṁ; beḷuvasalāṭukamattiyo hutvā billamattiyo ahesuṁ; billamattiyo hutvā pabhijjiṁsu;
analyzed: ahesu beḷu vasalāṭuka mattiyaḥ hutvā billa mattiyaḥ ahesu billa mattiyaḥ hutvā pabhijjisu
translated: the size of a bilva fruit, and burst open.
Blood and pus flowed out.

original: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu tenevābādhena kālamakāsi.
analyzed: atha kho kokālikaḥ bhikkhu tena iva ābādhena kālam akāsi
translated: Then the monk Kokālika died of that illness.

original: Kālaṅkato ca kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṁ nirayaṁ upapajji sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṁ āghātetvā.
analyzed: kālaṅkataḥ ca kokālikaḥ bhikkhu padumam nirayam upapajji sāriputta moggallānesu cittam āghātetvā
translated: And after his death he was reborn in the Paduma hell because of his ill will towards Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

original: Atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṁ jetavanaṁ
analyzed: atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkanta vaṇṇaḥ kevala kappam jetavana
translated: Then, when the night was well advanced, Brahmā Sahampati,🔽lighting up the whole Jetavana,

original: obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ
analyzed: obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamanta
translated: went up to the Buddha, bowed,

original: aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam ṭhitaḥ kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and stood to one side. Brahmā Sahampati said to the Buddha,
“Sir, the monk Kokālika has died.

original: kālaṅkato ca, bhante, kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṁ nirayaṁ upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṁ āghātetvā”ti.
analyzed: kālaṅkataḥ ca bhante kokālikaḥ bhikkhu padumam nirayam upapannaḥ sāriputta moggallānesu cittam āghātetvā ati
translated: And after he died, he was reborn in the Paduma hell because of his ill will towards Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
This is what Brahmā Sahampati said.

original: idaṁ vatvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
analyzed: idam vatvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā tattha iva antaradhāyi
translated: Then, after saying this, he paid homage to the Buddha, circumambulated him with his right side toward him, and disappeared right there.

original: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyāḥ accayena bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: The following morning the Buddha told the monks:

original: “imaṁ, bhikkhave, rattiṁ brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā …pe…
analyzed: bhikkhave rattim brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā pe
translated: “Last night, monks, Brahmā Sahampati …

original: idamavoca, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati, idaṁ vatvā maṁ padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.
analyzed: idam avoca bhikkhave brahmā sahampati idam vatvā mam padakkhiṇam katvā tattha iva antaradhāyi iti
translated: This is what Brahmā Sahampati said. After saying this, he paid homage to me, circumambulated me with his right side toward me, and disappeared right there.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When that was said, a certain monk said to the Buddha,

original: “kīvadīghaṁ nu kho, bhante, padume niraye āyuppamāṇan”ti?
analyzed: kīvadīgham nu kho bhante padume niraye āyu pamāṇam ti
translated: “How long is the lifespan in the Paduma hell, sir?”

analyzed: dīgham kho bhikkhu padume niraye āyu ppamāṇa
translated: “The lifespan in the Paduma hell is long,

original: taṁ na sukaraṁ saṅkhātuṁ ettakāni vassāni iti vā ettakāni vassasatāni iti vā ettakāni vassasahassāni iti vā ettakāni vassasatasahassāni iti vā”ti.
analyzed: tam na sukaram saṅkhātum ettakāni vassāni iti vā ettakāni vassa satāni iti vā ettakāni vassa sahassāni iti vā ettakāni vassa sata sahassāni iti vā ati
translated: It’s not easy to calculate how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”
“But, Sir, is it possible to give a simile?”
“It’s possible,” said the Buddha.

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho; tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṁ tilaṁ uddhareyya.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati khārikaḥ kosalakaḥ tila vāho tatas purisaḥ vassa satassa vassa satassa accayena ekam ekam tilam uddhareyya
translated: “Suppose there was a Kosalan cartload of twenty khāri of sesame seeds. And at the end of every century a man took a single seed from it.

original: Khippataraṁ kho so bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṁ pariyādānaṁ gaccheyya, na tveva eko abbudo nirayo.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati abbudā nirayā evameko nirabbudo nirayo.
analyzed: khippataram kho saḥ bhikkhu vīsati khārikaḥ kosalakaḥ tila vāhaḥ iminā upakkamena parikkhayam pariyādānam gaccheyya na tu eva ekaḥ abbudaḥ nirayaḥ  seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati abbudāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ nirabbudaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: The Kosalan cartload of twenty khāri of sesame seeds would be emptied in this way long before a single hell experience of the Abbuda hell would be exhausted.🔽Twenty times the life-span of the Abbuda hell is that of the Nirabbuda hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati nirabbudā nirayā evameko ababo nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati nirabbudāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ ababaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the life-span of the Nirabbuda hell is that of the Ababa hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ababā nirayā evameko aṭaṭo nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati ababāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ aṭaṭaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the life-span of the Ababa hell is that of the Aṭaṭa hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati aṭaṭā nirayā evameko ahaho nirayo.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ahahā nirayā evameko kumudo nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati aṭaṭāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ ahahaḥ nirayaḥ  seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati ahahā nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ kumudaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the suffering of the Aṭaṭa hell is the suffering of the Ahaha hell.🔽Twenty times the suffering of the Ahaha hell is the suffering of the Kuṇḍa hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati kumudā nirayā evameko sogandhiko nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati kumudāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ sogandhikaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the suffering of the Kuṇḍa hell is the suffering of the Sogandhika hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati sogandhikā nirayā evameko uppalako nirayo.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati uppalakā nirayā evameko puṇḍarīko nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati sogandhikāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ uppalakaḥ nirayaḥ  seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati uppalakāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ puṇḍarīkaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the suffering of the Sogandhika hell is the suffering of the Uppala hell.🔽Twenty times the suffering of the Uppala hell is the suffering of the Puṇḍarīka hell.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati puṇḍarīkā nirayā evameko padumo nirayo.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsati puṇḍarīkāḥ nirayāḥ evam ekaḥ padumaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: Twenty times the suffering of the Puṇḍarīka hell is the suffering of the Padma hell.

original: Padumaṁ kho pana bhikkhu nirayaṁ kokāliko bhikkhu upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṁ āghātetvā”ti.
analyzed: padumam kho pana bhikkhu nirayam kokālikaḥ bhikkhu upapannaḥ sāriputta moggallānesu cittam āghātetvā ati
translated: The monk Kokālika has been reborn in the Padma hell because of his ill will towards Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
The Buddha said this.

original: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
analyzed: idam vatvāna sugataḥ atha aparam etat avoca satthā
translated: And after saying this, the Happy One, the Teacher, further said:
“When a man is born,
a hatchet is born in his mouth.
With it he cuts himself,
the fool who speaks badly.
He who praises what should be criticized,
He who criticizes the one who should be praised,
With his mouth he creates a quarrel,

original: Kalinā tena sukhaṁ na vindati.🔽Appamatto ayaṁ kali,
analyzed: kalinā tena sukham na vindati  appamattaḥ ayam kali
translated: Through that quarrel he does not find happiness.🔽This is a small quarrel, the heedless one,
The loss of wealth through dice,
Even with all and with himself,
This is the greater quarrel;
The one who has ill-will towards the Well-Gone Ones.
A hundred thousand times a hundred thousand,
Thirty-six and five times a hundred thousand;
The one who reviles the Noble Ones goes to Hell,
Having set his evil speech and mind.
The one who speaks falsely goes to Hell,

original: Yo vāpi katvā na karomicāha;🔽Ubhopi te pecca samā bhavanti,
analyzed: yaḥ vā api katvā na karomi ca āha  ubhau api te samāḥ bhavanti
translated: Or the one who, having done, says 'I did not do';🔽Both of them, after death, are the same,
Human beings of low deeds in the next world.
The one who is angry with the one who is not angry,
With the pure person, the stainless one;
That evil returns to the foolish one,
Like fine dust thrown against the wind.
The one who is attached to the qualities of greed,
With his speech he reproaches others;
Faithless, miserly, and abusive,
Attached to envy and slander.
The mouth is foul, ignoble,
The body is evil, a doer of bad deeds;
The man is a scoundrel, despised,

analyzed: mā bahubhāṇidha na īrayikaḥ asi  rajamākirasī ahitāya
translated: Do not speak much, for you are a hell being.🔽You are covered with dust for your own harm,
You blame the peaceful one, you doer of evil;
Having done many bad actions,
You will go to the fall for a long time.
Indeed, no one's action is lost,
The one who has done good will obtain it;
The slow one sees suffering in the next world,
The doer of evil sees it in himself.
The place struck by the iron hammer,

analyzed: tiṇha dhāra maya sūlam upeti  atha
translated: Approaches the sharp-edged iron stake;🔽Then the food that is like a burning coal,

original: Bhojanamatthi tathā patirūpaṁ.🔽Na hi vaggu vadanti vadantā,
analyzed: bhojanam atthi tathā  na hi vaggu vadanti vadantā
translated: Is not suitable in that way.🔽Indeed, the beautiful ones do not speak when speaking,
They do not proclaim, they do not find refuge;
They lie down on a bed of burning coals,
They enter the burning fire.

analyzed: jālena ca onahiyāna  tattha hananti ayomayakuṭebhi
translated: And being dragged by a net,🔽There they are killed by iron houses;
Like the blind approaching darkness,
For it is spread out like a great body.
Then the iron pot,
And enter the burning furnace,
For there they are cooked for a long time,
In the wind that blows up the flames.
Then the blood and pus,
What is cooked there, the doer of evil?
Whatever direction he wishes to go,
There he is burned when he touches it.
In the prison of the Putrid Pool,
What is cooked there, the doer of evil?
For there is no shore to reach,
For all around it is full of foam.
But the forest of sword-leaves is sharp,
There they enter with their bodies cut up;
Seizing the tongue with a hook,
They pull it out, pulling it out again and again.
Then the difficult crossing, the difficult place,
They approach the razor-edged path;
There the slow fall,
The doers of evil, having done evil.

original: Khādanti hi tattha rudante,🔽Sāmā sabalā kākolagaṇā ca;
analyzed: khādanti hi tattha rudante  sāmā sabalā kākolagaṇā ca
translated: For there they are eaten, crying out,🔽The crows, the vultures, and the flocks of herons;
The tawny jackals and the greedy dogs,
The owls and the crows peck at them.
Difficult indeed is this life here,
Which a person touches, the doer of evil.
Therefore, while you have a life remaining,

analyzed: kicca karaḥ siyā naraḥ na ca ppamajje
translated: A person should do what is to be done and not be heedless.
Those who have been counted by the wise as sesame seeds,
Who have been led to the Paduma hell,
Are five hundred koṭis, and also
Twelve hundred koṭis and more.
As long as the suffering of the hells is spoken of here,
Even there one must live for a long time;
Therefore, in the qualities of good conduct, good friendship, and good advice,
One should always guard one’s speech and mind.”
The Discourse on Kokālika is the tenth.
